details.title: Assessing the Value of the Threshold Parameter in the Weibull Distribution Using Bayes Paradigm
details.standardTitle: Assessing the Value of the Threshold Parameter in the Weibull Distribution Using Bayes Paradigm

p: S. K. Upadhyay is a Professor with the Department of Statistics, Banaras Hindu University. He is also linked with DST Centre for Interdisciplinary Mathematical Sciences at Banaras Hindu University as a core group researcher. He obtained his M.Sc. (1980), and Ph.D. (1984) degrees from Banaras Hindu University; and started his teaching career as Lecturer in Statistics in the year 1981. He received a number of distinctions in his career, and worked as EEC research bursary at Imperial College, London, during the year 1992-93. His research interests include preliminary test procedures, life testing and reliability, and Bayes inference. He has published several research papers, books, and other academic materials in his career.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., Banaras Hindu Univ., Varanasi
authors.name: S. K. Upadhyay

p: Bhaswati Mukherjee was born in Bishnupur, India on 1981, Jan. 26. She obtained her B.Sc. (2000) from Purvanchal University, and M.Sc. (2002) degree in Statistics from Banaras Hindu University. She was awarded medals for securing the highest percentage of marks at both B.Sc. and M.Sc. levels. She started her teaching career as Lecturer in Statistics at Agrasen Kanya Autonomous P.G. College in the year 2002. Her research interests include Bayes inference, life testing, and reliability.

details.abstract: The Weibull distribution represents a wide variety of situations. Usually, the distribution is considered as a two-parameter family with a scale, and a shape parameter. If, however, the given data reflect additional information in the form of a minimum guarantee, a positive value away from zero, it is better to go for a three-parameter model with the additional parameter known as the threshold. The threshold parameter is often very important, but increases the complexity of the model. Arbitrarily going for the three-parameter form is not advisable unless it is really required by the data. This article attempts to make a simulation-based Bayesian study for checking if the threshold parameter can be taken to be zero or positive in situations representing the two models. We study the compatibility of the models for the given data set. We conduct the posterior simulation in each case using Gibbs sampling.

It is a Markovian updating scheme, which proceeds iteratively by generating variate values in a cyclic manner from the various full conditionals, which are specified up to proportionality from the joint posterior, the latter also being specified up to proportionality only [8].

To provide the implementation details of the algorithm for WB, we consider the LF corresponding to (1) as If we assume the joint prior for \$\Theta_{2}\$ as [8], [12] and combine (2) with (3) via Bayes' theorem, we get .
Reference [8] has given complete unrestricted analysis of the posterior corresponding to \${\rm WB}_{2}\$ under the same modeling assumption, so we get no advantage from repeating the details.

For numerical illustration, we considered two real data sets initially reported by [25] and [26], and later re analyzed by a number of authors assuming WB, lognormal, and generalized gamma distributions [5], [8], [27].
We next considered analyzing all the data sets using the GS algorithm on the lines of [8].

links.abstract: The authors obtain Bayes estimates of the parameters and reliability function of a 3-parameter Weibull distribution and compare posterior standard-deviation estimates with the corresponding asymptotic standard-deviation estimates of their maximum likelihood counterparts. Numerical examples are given.

context.text: Recently, [17] introduced the notion of DIC that considers a term corresponding to a measure of fit, and a term corresponding to a measure of complexity.

According to the authors, the residual information in data \$\underline{\rm x}\$ conditional on \$\Theta_{\rm j}\ ({\rm j}=1, 2)\$ may be defined (up to a multiplicative constant) as \$-2\log {\rm L}_{\rm j}(\underline{\rm x}\vert \Theta_{\rm j})\$, and it can be interpreted as a measure of surprise, logarithmic penalty, or uncertainty [17].

context.text: For numerical illustration, we considered two real data sets initially reported by [25] and [26], and later re analyzed by a number of authors assuming WB, lognormal, and generalized gamma distributions [5], [8], [27].
In a recent work [27] on Data 2, the authors recommended the \${\rm WB}_{2}\$ model in their comparison with the lognormal model.

For Data 2, we followed the suggestion given in [27] as the convergence of GS was found to be very poor for the fractional posterior corresponding to a fraction equal to \${\rm n}_{1}/{\rm n}\$, or a value close to it.
